p.s: In order to convince his audience of his opinion, Michel Barnier makes use of several rhetorical strategies.
In the text below, I will have a closer look on his choice of words, his line of arguments and the stylistic devices he employs.
In the first few lines Barnier is introducing to the speech by telling the issue he is talking about and his position regret (l. 1) the split of the UK from the EU.
So, firstly, he is announcing his topic in order to catch the audience's attention.
Secondly he goes on with the main part where he explains the consequences of Brexit, especially for the UK (ll. 4-10).
Then he continues with talking about the troubles and difficulties the UK will face when aiming to sign a deal with the US (cf. 11-14).
Thus he explains after that the EU should have a close relationship with the UK [...] in financial services (l. 15f.).
Lastly he refers to the regulation and supervision of third countries (ll. 21f.).
Barnier explains that the EU single market works well (l. 25) for the US and is wondering why it does not work for the UK (cf. l. 25f.).
In the conclusion of his text, he puts visions for the future forward of the EU market remaining the most open in the world and of the EU remaining itself without change after Brexit (cf. ll. 27ff.).

With the intention of making is easier for the audience to follow his train of thoughts he is structuring his text with the use of words such as first (l. 16), secondly (l. 21), which enhances the understanding of the audience.
In order to make sure that the audience can follow him he employs several strategies, for ex.
he asks a rhetorical question in l. 25-26 which makes the audience question why the EU market is not working for the EU.
The question is also helpful to manifest the audience's attention throughout the speech because of involving them.
Furthermore he is putting emphasis on his question due to the anaphora Why?[...] Why? (ll. 25-26) which stresses his point.

The frequent use of the first plurlarplural personal pronouns such as we (l. 2), we (l. 15), our (l. 16) gives the listeners the impression that he does not regard himself as superior to them but rather as one of them.
It also suggests that he is attempting to establish his personal relationship with the listeners.
Moreover, it is creating an illusion of solidarity and mutual understanding which makes it appear unreasonable not to agree with him and that way helping him to impose his opinion on his audience.
He is also drawing a sharp contrast between you [...] in the US (l. 22) and we [...] in the EU (l. 23) which again underlines those patterns of identification and solidarity.
To put emphasis on the importance of the EU market, he makes use of an enumeration in lines 20-30: that is more open, comprehensive, and rules-based.
The enumeration is also creating intensity, underlining the message of the speech.
With the purpose of leaving no doubt he makes frequent use of the adjectivadjective clear (l. 24, l. 27) and the adverb clearly (l. 9).
Barnier also employs another adverbsadverbs that lead to better understanding and create a stronger impact and imagery, for instance deeply (l. 1) and necessarily (l. 2).
Another much-used word is the verb will (l. 27, l. 28, l. 32) when talking about the future.
This employment makes Barnier appears determined and convinced of what he is saying which gives the impression that he is trustworthy and in return he is more convincing.

After the analysis of the speech of Michel Barnier, I have come to the conclusion that he is using several devices with the intention of catching the audience's attention, manifesting it, and winning the trust of the audience in establishing a personal relationship with them.
I think that he successfully appealed to the audience's heads and hearts.
